metadata.title: Benchmarking Neural Network Robustness to Common Corruptions and Perturbations
metadata.author: Dan Hendrycks and Thomas Dietterich
metadata.abstract: In this paper we establish rigorous benchmarks for image classifier robustness. Our first benchmark, IMAGENET-C, standardizes and expands the corruption robustness topic, while showing which classifiers are preferable in safety-critical applications. Then we propose a new dataset called IMAGENET-P which enables researchers to benchmark a classifier’s robustness to common perturbations. Unlike recent robustness research, this benchmark evaluates performance on common corruptions and perturbations not worst-case adversarial perturbations. We find that there are negligible changes in relative corruption robustness from AlexNet classifiers to ResNet classifiers. Afterward we discover ways to enhance corruption and perturbation robustness. We even find that a bypassed adversarial defense provides substantial common perturbation robustness. Together our benchmarks may aid future work toward networks that robustly generalize.

highlights: The human vision system is robust in ways that existing computer vision systems are not (Recht et al, 2018; Azulay & Weiss, 2018)
We introduced what are to our knowledge the first comprehensive benchmarks for corruption and perturbation robustness
The first of which showed that many years of architectural advancements corresponded to minuscule changes in relative corruption robustness
Thereafter we found that methods such as histogram equalization, multiscale architectures, and larger featureaggregating models improve corruption robustness

We found that even greater perturbation robustness can come from an adversarial defense designed for adversarial ∞ perturbations, indicating a surprising interaction between adversarial and common perturbation robustness

We found several methods to increase robustness, introduced novel experiments and metrics, and created new datasets for the rigorous study of model robustness, a pressing necessity as models are unleashed into safety-critical real-world settings
key_statements: The human vision system is robust in ways that existing computer vision systems are not (Recht et al, 2018; Azulay & Weiss, 2018)
Humans can even deal with abstract changes in structure and style. Achieving these kinds of robustness is an important goal for computer vision and machine learning
We introduce a total of three methods and architectures that improve corruption robustness without losing accuracy
We show that the Adversarial Logit Pairing ∞ adversarial example defense can yield substantial robustness gains on diverse and common perturbations
In order to approximate C, E and these robustness measures, we designed a set of corruptions and perturbations which are frequently encountered in natural images
Appearing more subtly than the corruption from IMAGENET-C, the Gaussian noise perturbation sequence begins with the clean ImageNet image
We introduce a more nuanced corruption robustness measure
The goal of IMAGENET-C and IMAGENET-P is to evaluate the robustness of machine learning algorithms on novel corruptions and perturbations

Be aware that Appendix F contains many informative failures in robustness enhancement. Those experiments underscore the necessity in testing on a a diverse test set, the difficulty in cleansing corruptions from image, and the futility in expecting robustness gains from some “simpler” models

Corruption robustness results are summarized in Figure 5. This shows that corruption robustness may be a better way to measure future progress in representation learning than the clean dataset top-1 error rate
We introduced what are to our knowledge the first comprehensive benchmarks for corruption and perturbation robustness
The first of which showed that many years of architectural advancements corresponded to minuscule changes in relative corruption robustness
Thereafter we found that methods such as histogram equalization, multiscale architectures, and larger featureaggregating models improve corruption robustness

We found that even greater perturbation robustness can come from an adversarial defense designed for adversarial ∞ perturbations, indicating a surprising interaction between adversarial and common perturbation robustness

We found several methods to increase robustness, introduced novel experiments and metrics, and created new datasets for the rigorous study of model robustness, a pressing necessity as models are unleashed into safety-critical real-world settings
summary: The human vision system is robust in ways that existing computer vision systems are not (Recht et al, 2018; Azulay & Weiss, 2018).
In order to approximate C, E and these robustness measures, we designed a set of corruptions and perturbations which are frequently encountered in natural images.
Research that improves performance on this benchmark should indicate general robustness gains, as the corruptions are diverse and numerous.
These algorithmically generated corruptions are applied to the ImageNet (Deng et al, 2009) validation images to produce our corruption robustness dataset IMAGENET-C.
The IMAGENET-C dataset consists of 75 corruptions, all applied to ImageNet validation images for testing a pre-existing network.

The dataset has validation perturbations; has difficulty levels; has CIFAR-10, Tiny ImageNet, ImageNet 64 × 64, standard, and Inception-sized editions; and has been designed for benchmarking not training networks.
Departs from IMAGENET-C by having perturbation sequences generated from each ImageNet validation image; examples are in Figure 2.
Appearing more subtly than the corruption from IMAGENET-C, the Gaussian noise perturbation sequence begins with the clean ImageNet image.
The following frames in the sequence consist in the same Figure 2: Example frames from the image but with minute Gaussian noise perturbations applied.
The goal of IMAGENET-C and IMAGENET-P is to evaluate the robustness of machine learning algorithms on novel corruptions and perturbations.

Those experiments underscore the necessity in testing on a a diverse test set, the difficulty in cleansing corruptions from image, and the futility in expecting robustness gains from some “simpler” models.

Multiscale architectures achieve greater corruption robustness by propagating features across scales at each layer rather than slowly gaining a global representation of the input as in typical convolutional neural networks.
These two different multiscale networks both enhance corruption robustness, but they do not provide any noticeable benefit in perturbation robustness.
This shows that corruption robustness may be a better way to measure future progress in representation learning than the clean dataset top-1 error rate.

ALP was designed to increase robustness to small gradient perturbations, it markedly improves robustness to all sorts of noise, blur, weather, and digital IMAGENET-P perturbations—methods generalizing this well is a rarity.
Thereafter we found that methods such as histogram equalization, multiscale architectures, and larger featureaggregating models improve corruption robustness.

We found several methods to increase robustness, introduced novel experiments and metrics, and created new datasets for the rigorous study of model robustness, a pressing necessity as models are unleashed into safety-critical real-world settings.
headline: We propose a new dataset called IMAGENET-P which enables researchers to benchmark a classifier’s robustness to common perturbations
